metadata.case_name: Employees of City of Nagpur Corporation v. City of Nagpur Corporation

facts.text: On July 13, 1964, Sitaram Madhorao, Chaukidar and 9 other employees of the Octroi Department of the Corporation filed an application under s. 20 of the Act in the Court of Small Causes at Nagpur, claiming overtime wages for period from 1-1-1964 to 30-6-1964, total Rs. 8670.18 plus Rs. 100 compensation.
Application presented through General Secretary of Nagpur Corporation Employees Association, registered trade union.

On June 26, 1964, T. R. Khante, Time-keeper and 13 other employees of the Water Works Department filed similar application under s. 20, claiming overtime from 1-8-63 to 31-1-64, total Rs. 1987.48 later stated as Rs. 1047.48 plus Rs. 140 compensation.
Minimum wages notification issued on 21-2-1951 fixing Re. 1-12 per day for eight hours for employment under local authority.
Revised minimum wages notification on 23-2-1956 superseding 1951 notification for scheduled employment under local authority.
On November 10, 1964, Authority disallowed preliminary objections by Corporation and directed trial on merits.

On February 17, 1965, Authority held: wireman skilled, time-keeper and lineman semi-skilled (issue 1); 1956 notification only for unskilled labour (issue 2); no entitlement for work on Sundays absent s.13(1)(c) provision (issue 3); chowkidars and motor-drivers no excess hours (issue 4). Dismissed applications with costs.
Four special civil applications under Art. 227 filed in Bombay High Court, Nagpur Bench.
Bombay High Court on August 19, 1966 dismissed applications: held 1956 notification applies to all employees, but ordinary rate in r.25 means minimum rate, following Union of India v. B. Rathi.
Sunday declared day of rest, normal hours 9 hours/day or 54 hours/week.

legal_issues.text: Whether 'ordinary rate of wages' in r.25 of M.P. Minimum Wages Rules means actual wages received by worker or minimum wages fixed under the Act for overtime payments.
Scope of 1956 notification: confined to unskilled labour or applicable to all employees of local authority.
Whether applicants (skilled/semi-skilled) can claim under s.20; entitlement for work on weekly rest days (Sundays).
Whether chowkidars and motor-drivers worked excess hours.

petitioner_arguments.text: Words 'at double the ordinary rate of wages' in cl. (b) of r.25 mean double the rate of wages actually being paid to employees, not double the minimum wages fixed under the Act.
Applicants entitled to overtime wages for excess hours and holidays, and wages for work on Sundays.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Minimum Wages Act s.20; notifications 1951 and 1956

respondent_arguments.text: Ordinary rate of wages in r.25 means ordinary minimum rate of wages fixed under the Act; employees paid higher than minimum, so no obligation under Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 25 M.P. Minimum Wages Rules; s.14 Minimum Wages Act

respondent_arguments.text: 1956 notification confined to unskilled labour including casual labour, as per its terms superseding only those rates in 1951 notification.

court_reasoning.text: Act aimed at preventing exploitation; r.25 'ordinary rate of wages' means actual remuneration worker ordinarily receives, not minimum wages; double actual rate intended as minimum for overtime to provide real benefit and inducement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Phrase reflects actuality rather than minimum entitlement; respondents' view deprives workers of benefit.

court_reasoning.text: 1956 notification to be read with 1951; confined to unskilled labour as it revises those rates without deleting 'unskilled'; High Court wrong in extending to all.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Later notification fitted into earlier without expanding scope.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished Union of India v. B. Rathi AIR 1963 Bom 54; s.14 and Railway Rules do not compel minimum rate interpretation; liberal approach needed for worker benefit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Focus on actual benefit for overtime inducement.

holdings.text: 'Ordinary rate of wages' in r.25(b) means basic wage plus allowances actually entitled to, double for overtime.

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. B. Rathi
precedents_cited.relevance: Held ordinary rate means minimum rate; disagreed as it ignores actual benefit to workers.

precedents_cited.case_name: Municipal Borough, Bijapur v. Gundawan M.N. ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar view to B. Rathi on ordinary rate.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chairman of the Madras Port Trust v. Claims Authority ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar view to B. Rathi on ordinary rate.

statutes_cited.name: Minimum Wages Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Fixing minimum wages, overtime, claims by employees, notifications, rest days.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court supervisory jurisdiction over Authority.

statutes_cited.name: M.P. Minimum Wages Rules, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Extra wages for overtime at double ordinary rate.

statutes_cited.name: Factories Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: r.25 not to affect its provisions.

outcome.summary: Appeals allowed; High Court correct on 1956 notification limited to unskilled but wrong on r.25 ordinary rate meaning actual wages; remitted to Authority for fresh decision in light of observations.
outcome.relief_granted: Case remanded to Authority under Minimum Wages Act for fresh decision.

key_quotes.text: By using the phrase double the ordinary rate of wages the rule-making authority seems to us to have intended that the worker should be the recipient of double the remuneration which he, in fact, ordinarily receives and not double the rate of minimum wages fixed for him under the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on interpretation of r.25.

key_quotes.text: The interpretation suggested on behalf of the respondents would have the effect of depriving most of the workers who are actually getting more than the minimum wages fixed under the Act of the full benefit of the plain language of r. 25.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why minimum rate view is rejected.

key_quotes.text: The 1956 notification has to be read in the background of the 1951 notification with the result that the later notification must also be held to be confined to unskilled labour.
key_quotes.speaker: court
